author: djrtwo
content: <@322222239850168331> A followup -- Casper is designed in such a way that favors liveness. Disagreeing on the current epoch does not prevent the chain from continuing to be built and to find consensus at a subsequent epoch. The "Plausible Liveness" claim in the FFG paper shows that the chain can finalize future epochs (without requiring slashing honest actors) regardless of any votes previously cast.

author: protolambda
content:
Ok, I am going to repeat the request for teams to not pull in the ETH 2.0 spec tests every single CI run through LFS. It slows down your clones, consumes a lot of bandwidth, and some of you don't seem to even cache it, while it's multiple GB big. That is just insane. And meanwhile the githbub plan is still fronting a lot of bandwidth (we bought some a while ago, but it ran out super quick, like under an hour quick), and I am sure they are starting to be done with us, as someone reported to have problems pulling down through LFS.

Have a look at this graph:

author: mpetrunic
content: You have it here for free: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@chainsafe/eth2-spec-tests

author: protolambda
content: that's 6000+ spec tests LFS clones over the last 20 days. Each multiple GB of bandwidth (worst case, some may be cached and much, but some may not, and then it gets bad real fast)

author: protolambda
content: Please, start using the gzipped tarballs (you can find them on the release page for every release!). It's nicely split up in configuration, separates SSZ-generic and BLS. And is much, much cheaper on bandwidth (it's compressed, and not billed by github)
